newsitem.title: GREECE: Greece signs EIB loan for Elefsis highway.
newsitem.headline: Greece signs EIB loan for Elefsis highway.

text.p: The European Investment Bank (EIB) signed over to Greece the first tranche of a 265 billion drachma ($1.08 billion) loan to build a peripheral motorway around Athens, servicing the capital's planned new international airport.
National Economy Minister Yannos Papantoniou and EIB vice-president Panagiotis Gennimatas signed the agreement for the first 45 billion drachma tranche at a ceremony in Athens.
The road is a main element in the development of the new Athens international airport, under construction at Spata east of the capital.

Papantoniou said that a "fruitful co-operation between the government and the EIB on three other major construction projects -- the Spata airport, a natural gas pipeline and the Rio-Antirio bridge -- had already been established."

The EIB approved a 265 billion drachma loan facility for the Elefsis-Stavros-Spata-Imittos highway in July. The balance of 220 billion drachmas will be arranged with Concessionaire Attiki Odos S.A. and paid in tranches as the highway proceeds.
Gennimatas said that "in 1996 we approved four important construction projects that I consider as the hard core of Greece's construction activity."

He added: "I consider the most difficult of the four projects is the Elefsis-Stavros highway. Its difficulties arise from the very high estimated cost as well as its exceptionally high technical standards and requirements."
"Another difficulty is the fact that the highway will be passing through populated areas," he added. There are 14 Greek companies in the construction consortium, headed by Aktor.
The Elefsis-Stavros project is part of the PATHE axis, a key project in the priority list of Trans-European Network projects (TENs), approved by the Essen European Council.
The Elefsis highway is expected to create 2,000 permanent jobs.
